segment.source: This article explains how to receive content in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app shared from another app using Share contract.
segment.target: This article explains how to receive content in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app shared from another app using Share contract.

segment.source: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.
segment.target: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.

segment.source: Receive data
segment.target: Receive data

segment.source: Receive data
segment.target: Receive data

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: This article explains how to receive content in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app shared from another app using Share contract.
segment.target: This article explains how to receive content in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app shared from another app using Share contract.

segment.source: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.
segment.target: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.

segment.source: Declare your app as a share target
segment.target: Declare your app as a share target

segment.source: The system displays a list of possible target apps when a user invokes Share.
segment.target: The system displays a list of possible target apps when a user invokes Share.

segment.source: In order to appear on the list, your app need to declare that it supports the Share contract.
segment.target: In order to appear on the list, your app need to declare that it supports the Share contract.

segment.source: This lets the system know that your app is available to receive content.
segment.target: This lets the system know that your app is available to receive content.

segment.source: Open the manifest file.
segment.target: Open the manifest file.

segment.source: It should be called something like package.appxmanifest.
segment.target: It should be called something like package.appxmanifest.

segment.source: Open the Declarations tab.
segment.target: Open the Declarations tab.

segment.source: Choose Share Target from the Available Declarations list and click Add.
segment.target: Choose Share Target from the Available Declarations list and click Add.

segment.source: Choose file types and formats
segment.target: Choose file types and formats

segment.source: Next, decide what file types and data formats you support.
segment.target: Next, decide what file types and data formats you support.

segment.source: The Share APIs support several standard formats, such as Text, HTML, and Bitmap.
segment.target: The Share APIs support several standard formats, such as Text, HTML, and Bitmap.

segment.source: You can also specify custom file types and data formats.
segment.target: You can also specify custom file types and data formats.

segment.source: If you do, remember that source apps have to know what those types and formats are, otherwise those apps can't use the formats to share data.
segment.target: If you do, remember that source apps have to know what those types and formats are, otherwise those apps can't use the formats to share data.

segment.source: Only register for formats your app can handle.
segment.target: Only register for formats your app can handle.

segment.source: Only target apps that support the data being shared appear when the user invokes share.
segment.target: Only target apps that support the data being shared appear when the user invokes share.

segment.source: To set file types:
segment.target: To set file types:

segment.source: Open the manifest file.
segment.target: Open the manifest file.

segment.source: It should be called something like package.appxmanifest.
segment.target: It should be called something like package.appxmanifest.

segment.source: In the Supported File Types section of the Declarations page, click Add New.
segment.target: In the Supported File Types section of the Declarations page, click Add New.

segment.source: Type the file name extension that you want to support.
segment.target: Type the file name extension that you want to support.

segment.source: For example, .docx.
segment.target: For example, .docx.

segment.source: You need to include the period.
segment.target: You need to include the period.

segment.source: If you want to support all file types, check the SupportsAnyFileType box.
segment.target: If you want to support all file types, check the SupportsAnyFileType box.

segment.source: To set data formats:
segment.target: To set data formats:

segment.source: Open the manifest file.
segment.target: Open the manifest file.

segment.source: Open the Data Formats section of the Declarations page and click Add New.
segment.target: Open the Data Formats section of the Declarations page and click Add New.

segment.source: Type the name of the data format you support.
segment.target: Type the name of the data format you support.

segment.source: For example, "Text".
segment.target: For example, "Text".

segment.source: Handle share activation
segment.target: Handle share activation

segment.source: When a user selects your app (usually by selecting it from a list of available target apps in the share UI), an Application.OnShareTargetActivatedOnShareTargetActivated event is raised.
segment.target: When a user selects your app (usually by selecting it from a list of available target apps in the share UI), an Application.OnShareTargetActivatedOnShareTargetActivated event is raised.

segment.source: Your app needs to handle this event to process the data the user wants to share.
segment.target: Your app needs to handle this event to process the data the user wants to share.

segment.source: Note that if your app is running when it is activated as a Share target, the existing instance of your app is terminated and a new instance of your app is launched to handle the contract.
segment.target: Note that if your app is running when it is activated as a Share target, the existing instance of your app is terminated and a new instance of your app is launched to handle the contract.

segment.source: The data that the user wants to share is contained in a ShareOperation object.
segment.target: The data that the user wants to share is contained in a ShareOperation object.

segment.source: You can use this object to check the format of the data it contains.
segment.target: You can use this object to check the format of the data it contains.

segment.source: Report sharing status
segment.target: Report sharing status

segment.source: In some cases, it can take time for your app to process the data it wants to share.
segment.target: In some cases, it can take time for your app to process the data it wants to share.

segment.source: Examples include users sharing collections of files or images.
segment.target: Examples include users sharing collections of files or images.

segment.source: These items are larger than a simple text string, so they take longer to process.
segment.target: These items are larger than a simple text string, so they take longer to process.

segment.source: After calling ReportStartedReportStarted, don't expect any more user interaction with your app.
segment.target: After calling ReportStartedReportStarted, don't expect any more user interaction with your app.

segment.source: As a result, you shouldn't call it unless your app is at a point where it can be dismissed by the user.
segment.target: As a result, you shouldn't call it unless your app is at a point where it can be dismissed by the user.

segment.source: With an extended share, it's possible that the user might dismiss the source app before your app has all the data from the DataPackage object.
segment.target: With an extended share, it's possible that the user might dismiss the source app before your app has all the data from the DataPackage object.

segment.source: As a result, we recommend that you let the system know when your app has acquired the data it needs.
segment.target: As a result, we recommend that you let the system know when your app has acquired the data it needs.

segment.source: This way, the system can suspend or terminate the source app as necessary.
segment.target: This way, the system can suspend or terminate the source app as necessary.

segment.source: If something goes wrong, call ReportErrorReportError to send an error message to the system.
segment.target: If something goes wrong, call ReportErrorReportError to send an error message to the system.

segment.source: The user will see the message when they check on the status of the share.
segment.target: The user will see the message when they check on the status of the share.

segment.source: At that point, your app is shut down and the share is ended.
segment.target: At that point, your app is shut down and the share is ended.

segment.source: The user will need to start again to share the content to your app.
segment.target: The user will need to start again to share the content to your app.

segment.source: Depending on your scenario, you may decide that a particular error isn't serious enough to end the share operation.
segment.target: Depending on your scenario, you may decide that a particular error isn't serious enough to end the share operation.

segment.source: In that case, you can choose to not call ReportError and to continue with the share.
segment.target: In that case, you can choose to not call ReportError and to continue with the share.

segment.source: Finally, when your app has successfully processed the shared content, you should call ReportCompletedReportCompleted to let the system know.
segment.target: Finally, when your app has successfully processed the shared content, you should call ReportCompletedReportCompleted to let the system know.

segment.source: When you use these methods, you usually call them in the order just described, and you don't call them more than once.
segment.target: When you use these methods, you usually call them in the order just described, and you don't call them more than once.

segment.source: However, there are times when a target app can call ReportDataRetrievedReportDataRetrieved before ReportStartedReportStarted.
segment.target: However, there are times when a target app can call ReportDataRetrievedReportDataRetrieved before ReportStartedReportStarted.

segment.source: For example, the app might retrieve the data as part of a task in the activation handler, but not call ReportStarted until the user clicks a Share button.
segment.target: For example, the app might retrieve the data as part of a task in the activation handler, but not call ReportStarted until the user clicks a Share button.

segment.source: Return a QuickLink if sharing was successful
segment.target: Return a QuickLink if sharing was successful

segment.source: When a user selects your app to receive content, we recommend that you create a QuickLinkQuickLink.
segment.target: When a user selects your app to receive content, we recommend that you create a QuickLinkQuickLink.

segment.source: A QuickLink is like a shortcut that makes it easier for users to share information with your app.
segment.target: A QuickLink is like a shortcut that makes it easier for users to share information with your app.

segment.source: For example, you could create a QuickLink that opens a new mail message pre-configured with a friend's email address.
segment.target: For example, you could create a QuickLink that opens a new mail message pre-configured with a friend's email address.

segment.source: A QuickLink must have a title, an icon, and an Id.
segment.target: A QuickLink must have a title, an icon, and an Id.

segment.source: The title (like "Email Mom") and icon appear when the user taps the Share charm.
segment.target: The title (like "Email Mom") and icon appear when the user taps the Share charm.

segment.source: The Id is what your app uses to access any custom information, such as an email address or login credentials.
segment.target: The Id is what your app uses to access any custom information, such as an email address or login credentials.

segment.source: When your app creates a QuickLink, the app returns the QuickLink to the system by calling ReportCompletedReportCompleted.
segment.target: When your app creates a QuickLink, the app returns the QuickLink to the system by calling ReportCompletedReportCompleted.

segment.source: A QuickLink does not actually store data.
segment.target: A QuickLink does not actually store data.

segment.source: Instead, it contains an identifier that, when selected, is sent to your app.
segment.target: Instead, it contains an identifier that, when selected, is sent to your app.

segment.source: Your app is responsible for storing the Id of the QuickLink and the corresponding user data.
segment.target: Your app is responsible for storing the Id of the QuickLink and the corresponding user data.

segment.source: When the user taps the QuickLink, you can get its Id through the ShareOperation.QuickLinkIdQuickLInkId property.
segment.target: When the user taps the QuickLink, you can get its Id through the ShareOperation.QuickLinkIdQuickLInkId property.
